steps.name: Placing the shelf
steps.text: Most herbs need a lot of sunlight. Try to place your shelving unit near a window that gets several hours of direct sunlight per day. This will likely be a south- or west-facing window. If your shelving unit has adjustable shelf heights, ensure that as many shelves as possible will receive direct sunlight. Leave enough space between the shelves to avoid squishing the plant.

steps.name: Watering
steps.text: Your herbs probably require less water than you think. You will need to water them once every 2-3 days. To check whether your plants need water, stick your finger about 2 knuckles into the soil. It should be consistently moist, but not waterlogged. If the soil does not drain properly when you water the herbs, or if the leaves of the herbs begin to wilt and turn yellow, try watering your herbs less frequently. Note that the more sunlight your plants get, the more frequently you should water them.

steps.name: Harvesting
steps.text: Use a pair of scissors, or pinch gently with your fingers to harvest your herbs. Try to harvest regularly to encourage growth (at least once a week), but avoid removing more than a third of the herbs leaves at a time, as this can kill the plant.

steps.name: Setting up base
steps.text:
For the base, you can use preserved reindeer moss, decorative sand, small rocks, seashells, bark, marbles, etc. The possibilities are endless when it comes to colors and textures of sand and rock for terrariums so have fun with it! You donâ€™t need soil for your air plants to thrive, so no need to include it here.
 You don't want your air plants sitting against any moisture in their terrariums or holders, so make sure whatever base you use is completely dry.

steps.name: Watering
steps.text:
Make sure not to water your plants while they are inside your terrarium, as this can cause too much moisture to stay trapped amongst the moss, rock, etc. and cause your plants to rot.

Take the plants out and soak/mist them and then make sure they arecompletely dry before adding them back into your terrarium.

There should be no water or condensation in your terrarium or sitting against the Tillandsia.

steps.name: Long term care
steps.text: Air plants need light, air, and water to survive.  Air Plant care will also depend on the type of environment you are housing them in as well as the type of tillandsia you have.  As a general rule xeric (silver leafed) plants will like drier conditions and more sunlight, while mesic (greener leafed) type plants will like more moisture and lower indirect light levels.

steps.name: Repot
steps.text: Tropical plants thrive in partial or indirect sunlight making them the perfect plants for a bright corner in your home. To begin, repot each plant in a separate planter and place a drainage tray under the planter. Placing the plants in a new environment can be shocking, but a good watering will help them adjust. Make sure to give the plants some water right after repotting them.

steps.name: Set up
steps.text: Place the plant stand in your chosen corner. Put one of your plants on top of the plant stand and place the other on the floor in front of the stand. The plants should be arranged so that the plant in front is not shading the plant in the back. This will help all the plants get equal amounts of light.

steps.name: Watering & Care
steps.text: Tropical plants tend to need water every 7-10 days. You can check the moisture level of the soil by placing your finger about an inch into the soil. If the soil feels dry all the way through, that means it's time to water the plant. After some time, you may notice dust start to build up on the leaves on your plant. If this happens, wipe the leaves with a clean, damp cloth.
